info.game_comments:
Isaac Segal game 4.
Last regular play game of Season 11.

(1, 1).clue: On December 19 the people of this U.S. state celebrate Princess Bernice Pauahi Bishop's birthday

(2, 1).clue: In 1967 this New York Jets quarterback became the first pro to pass for more than 4,000 yards in a season

(3, 1).clue: The name of this food, not a true grain, comes from the Dutch meaning "beech wheat"

(4, 1).clue: On April 5, 1614, in Jamestown, she married John Rolfe

(5, 1).clue: Since 1908 this group has distributed over 26 million Bibles to hotels & other institutions

(6, 1).clue: It's the 4-letter word that "makes the world go round"

(1, 2).clue: In 1986 this New York capital celebrated the 300th anniversary of its charter as a city

(2, 2).clue: Founded in 1897, it's the world's oldest annual marathon

(3, 2).clue: The rolled form of this grain cooks in about 5 minutes; the steel-cut takes much longer

(4, 2).clue: Anna Ivanovna, empress of Russia from 1730 to 1740, was the niece of this great ruler

(5, 2).clue: It's what the R stands for in AARP

(1, 3).clue: This U.S. first lady once taught dance in Grand Rapids

(2, 3).clue: In 1991, after 12 seasons at the Salt Palace, this NBA team moved its home games to the Delta Center

(3, 3).clue: Basmati, an aromatic type of this grain, is grown in India

(4, 3).clue: After 5 years in office, she resigned as Israeli prime minister in 1974

(5, 3).clue: Not surprisingly, this organization, founded in 1884, maintains one of the world's finest reference libraries on dogs

(6, 3).clue: It's the type of pot that "never boils"

(1, 4).clue: Lancaster, which has the largest stockyards east of Chicago, was this state's capital from 1799 to 1812

(2, 4).clue: In 1992 Viktor Petrenko won the world championship in this sport

(3, 4).clue: Millet seed, an important food for North Africans, is most often fed to these pets in the U.S.

(4, 4).clue: The proceeds from some of her souvenir hatchets helped fund a home for wives of alcoholics

(5, 4).clue: Members of this volunteer crime-fighting organization are famous for wearing red berets

(1, 5).clue: This Connecticut city famous for its university is nicknamed "Elm City" because it once had many elm-lined streets

(2, 5).clue: During his 1955-1966 career, this Dodger pitcher averaged 9.28 strikeouts per 9 innings

(3, 5).clue: The pot type of this grain retains more of the bran than the pearl type

(4, 5).clue: In 1813 this mistress of the late Lord Nelson was imprisoned for debt

(5, 5).clue: During Egypt's suspension from this group, 1979-1989, its headquarters was located in Tunisia

(6, 5).clue: "Every" one of these "fits not every foot"

(1, 1).clue: A smaller canal connecting to this river brings fresh water to the Suez Canal

(3, 1).clue: This author of "The Time Machine" coined the phrase "the war that will end war"

(4, 1).clue: On December 10 he announced he'd leave his Hyde Park estate & its papers & books to the U.S. government

(5, 1).clue: Barbra Streisand introduced the song "People" in this musical

(1, 2).clue: Many things in Hong Kong are named for this queen, including the mountain peak on Hong Kong island

(3, 2).clue: This author gave us the line "I'll make him an offer he can't refuse"

(4, 2).clue: By accepting his membership dues, the League of Nations recognized him as emperor of Ethiopia

(5, 2).clue: In 1994 Brooke Shields made her Broadway debut as Betty Rizzo in this musical

(1, 3).clue: Lake Avernus in Campania in this country was believed by the ancients to be the entrance to Hades

(2, 3).clue: The U.S. pavilion at Montreal's Expo 67 was covered by one of these

(3, 3).clue: This "Return of the Native" author's first novel, "Desperate Remedies", was published in 1871

(4, 3).clue: 17 acres surrounding her cottage were transferred to the Shakespeare Birthplace Trust

(5, 3).clue: 1992's "Hello Muddah, Hello Fadduh!" was inspired by the comic songs of this man

(6, 3).clue: This father of Andrew Wyeth illustrated more than 20 juvenile classics, including "Treasure Island"

(1, 4).clue: The western portion of the Baltic island of Usedom belongs to Germany; the eastern, to this country

(2, 4).clue: Lighter than steel, this metal is also associated with the Modernist style of the '20s & '30s

(3, 4).clue: This Dr. Dolittle creator studied civil engineering at M.I.T.

(4, 4).clue: Returning from Ireland to NYC in August, this aviator was given a parade down…er, up Broadway

(5, 4).clue: 1966 Jerry Herman musical that features the following:"For we need a little Christmas /Right this very minute /Candles in the window /Carols at the spinet /Yes, we need a little Christmas /Right this very minute /It hasn't snowed a single flurry /But Santa, dear, we're in a hurry /So climb down the chimney /Put up the brightest string of lights I've ever seen..."

(6, 4).clue: Born in South Carolina in 1782, he was known as a "war hawk" because he supported the War of 1812

(1, 5).clue: Boothia Peninsula in this country is the former location of the north magnetic pole

(2, 5).clue: The firm of Piano & Rogers is famous for this high-tech Paris landmark built 1971-77

(3, 5).clue: 1 of only 3 authors to win 2 Pulitzer Prizes for Fiction

(4, 5).clue: On April 27, 1938 Countess Geraldine Apponyi of Hungary married King Zog of this country

(5, 5).clue: "Cabaret" was based partly on this 1951 play by John Van Druten

(6, 5).clue: When the parents of this "pathfinder" ran off together, his mother was still legally married to another man

(0, 0).clue: Oscar Collazo, serving a life sentence for his assassination attempt on this president, was released in 1979
